message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and presentation suggest hypothyroidism, which is often caused by Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Lymphocytic infiltration, Hürthle cells, and germinal centers are characteristic findings of Hashimoto's thyroiditis on biopsy. Options A, B, and C are characteristic of other thyroid disorders such as papillary thyroid carcinoma, anaplastic carcinoma, and follicular carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the presence of antibodies against thyroid peroxidase suggest Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Hashimoto's thyroiditis is characterized by lymphocytic infiltration, Hürthle cells, and germinal centers on biopsy. None of the other options match the classic findings of Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of antibodies against thyroid peroxidase suggests autoimmune thyroiditis. The biopsy is most likely to show lymphocytic infiltration, Hürthle cells, and germinal centers, which are characteristic of Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Option A is characteristic of papillary thyroid carcinoma, option B is characteristic of anaplastic thyroid carcinoma, and option C is characteristic of subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (De Quervain thyroiditis).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest hypothyroidism and an enlarged thyroid gland. Antibodies against thyroid peroxidase suggest Hashimoto's thyroiditis, which is characterized by lymphocytic infiltration, Hürthle cells, and germinal centers on biopsy. All other options are characteristic of thyroid cancer or other thyroid disorders.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest hypothyroidism which is commonly caused by Hashimoto's thyroiditis. The presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies confirms the diagnosis. Biopsy of the thyroid gland in Hashimoto's thyroiditis typically shows lymphocytic infiltration, Hürthle cells, and germinal centers, which are seen in option D. Option A describes papillary thyroid carcinoma, option B describes anaplastic thyroid carcinoma, and option C describes follicular thyroid carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest hypothyroidism and a biopsy of the thyroid gland with antibodies against thyroid peroxidase suggest autoimmune thyroiditis. Among the options, only option D lists lymphocytic infiltration and Hürthle cells, which are commonly seen in autoimmune thyroiditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of hypothyroidism, with antibodies against thyroid peroxidase, suggesting Hashimoto's thyroiditis. An enlarged thyroid gland without any nodules or other suspicious features makes option A less likely. Option B describes features of anaplastic thyroid carcinoma, which is an aggressive cancer that would present differently. Option C describes features of thyroiditis, but not specifically Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Option D describes the classic findings in Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the presence of anti-thyroid peroxidase antibodies suggest autoimmune thyroiditis or Hashimoto's thyroiditis. A biopsy of the thyroid gland in this case will most likely show lymphocytic infiltration, Hürthle cells, and germinal centers. Option A describes papillary thyroid carcinoma, Option B describes anaplastic thyroid carcinoma, and Option C describes subacute thyroiditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of hypothyroidism, with a painless thyroid enlargement and positive antibodies against thyroid peroxidase. Among the options, only (D) describes the pathology seen in Hashimoto's thyroiditis, the most common cause of hypothyroidism. The biopsy will show lymphocytic infiltration, Hürthle cells, and germinal centers. Large, irregular nuclei, nuclear grooves, and Psammoma bodies are seen in papillary thyroid carcinoma. Spindle cells, pleomorphic giant cells, and mitotic figures are seen in anaplastic carcinoma. Multinucleated giant cells, macrophages, and degenerated follicular cells are seen in subacute thyroiditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest autoimmune thyroiditis, also called Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Biopsy of the thyroid gland would most likely show lymphocytic infiltration, Hürthle cells (aka oncocytic cells), and germinal centers. Option A describes papillary thyroid carcinoma, option B describes anaplastic thyroid carcinoma, and option C describes subacute thyroiditis.
